    • Method Detail

      • boxClass

        public static Class<?> boxClass(Class<?> c)
        Given a primitive type, return its boxed representation.

        Examples: boxClass(int.class) -> Integer.class boxClass(String.class) -> String.class

        Parameters:
        c - The class to be boxed.
        Returns:
        The boxed version of c, or c if it is not a primitive type.

      • classAndAncestors

        public static Iterable<Type> classAndAncestors(Type c)
        Given a Type, return all of the classes it extends and interfaces it implements (including the class itself).

        Examples: Integer.class -> {Integer.class, Number.class, Object.class} T -> Object ? -> Object HashSet -> {HashSet, Set, Collection, Object} FooEventHandler -> {FooEventHandler, EventHandler, Object}

      • isCoercable

        public static boolean isCoercable(Class<?> to,
                  Class<?> from)
        Check to see if one class can be coerced into another. A class is coercable to another if, once both are boxed, the target class is a superclass or implemented interface of the source class.

        If both classes are numeric types, then this method returns true iff the conversion will not result in a loss of precision.

        TODO: Float and double are currently coercible to int and long. This is a bug.

      • classForName

        public static Class<?> classForName(String name,
                    ClassLoader loader)
                             throws ClassNotFoundException
        Lookup the provided name using the provided classloader. This method includes special handling for primitive types, which can be looked up by short name (all other types need to be looked up by long name).
        Throws:
        ClassNotFoundException

      • getSimpleName

        public static String getSimpleName(Type name)
        Get the simple name of the class. This varies from the one in Class, in that it returns "1" for Classes like java.lang.String$1 In contrast, String.class.getSimpleName() returns "", which is not unique if java.lang.String$2 exists, causing all sorts of strange bugs.
        Parameters:
        name -
        Returns:

      • getFullName

        public static String getFullName(Type name)
        Return the full name of the raw type of the provided Type.

        Examples:

        java.lang.String.class -> "java.lang.String" Set -> "java.util.Set" // such types can occur as constructor arguments, for example

        Parameters:
        name -
        Returns:

      • getFullName

        public static String getFullName(Field f)
        Return the full name of the provided field. This will be globally unique. Following Java semantics, the full name will have all the generic parameters stripped out of it.

        Example:

        Set { int size; } -> java.util.Set.size

      • getInterfaceTarget

        public static Type getInterfaceTarget(Class<?> iface,
                      Type type)
                               throws IllegalArgumentException
        This method takes a class called clazz that *directly* implements a generic interface or generic class, iface. Iface should take a single parameter, which this method will return.

        TODO This is only tested for interfaces, and the type parameters associated with method arguments. TODO Not sure what we should do in the face of deeply nested generics (eg: Set) TODO Recurse up the class hierarchy in case there are intermediate interfaces

        Parameters:
        iface - A generic interface; we're looking up it's first (and only) parameter.
        type - A type that is more specific than clazz, or clazz if no such type is available.
        Returns:
        The class implemented by the interface, or null(?) if the instantiation was not generic.
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - if clazz does not directly implement iface.

      • getNamedParameterTargetOrNull

        public static Type getNamedParameterTargetOrNull(Class<?> clazz)
                                          throws ClassHierarchyException
        Parameters:
        clazz -
        Returns:
        T if clazz implements Name, null otherwise
        Throws:
        BindException - If clazz's definition incorrectly uses Name or @NamedParameter
        ClassHierarchyException

      • getRawClass

        public static Class<?> getRawClass(Type clazz)
        Coerce a Type into a Class. This strips out any generic paramters, and resolves wildcards and free parameters to Object.

        Examples: java.util.Set -> java.util.Set ? extends T -> Object T -> Object ? -> Object
